comment.author: 21686909@N07
comment._content: I don't get it.  Why is the Smithsonian posting all these run of the mill snap shots?  This is another poorly composed, out of focus photo.  It's a camel in a zoo.  At least, I can understand having photos of public buildings in Washington at different periods of time, but there must be thousands of other better photos taken during the twenties.

comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content: We appreciate your interest in the Smithsonian Institution Archives! As the Archives, in the business of preserving Institutional history, we take in a range of materials. Many times, these materials serve to document collections and/or conditions at a specific point in time and from a unique perspective. In this case, a visitor c. 1919. A simple snapshot may appear mundane to some. To a Smithsonian archivist, it is often a magnificent key to unlocking Institutional history. We're excited to share that with The Commons on Flickr community.

comment.author: 27197915@N08
comment._content:
A photograph is a snapshot of time, budderflyman, and even if it isn't 
compositionally to your liking or out of focus it still has a place.  I enjoy seeing these photographs (even the "run of the mill" ones), so keep it up Smithsonian, you're doing a great job preserving history!

comment.author: 21686909@N07
comment._content: The Smithsonian has to have millions of other photos that can better "serve to document collections and/or conditions at a specific point in time".  It's a bad photo of an ordinary camel in a zoo.  I just think time is wasted with shots like this when I know you have tons of fantastic historical photographs.  I don't view this as an historic photograph.  That's my point.
